I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Uzbekistan requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to support present and planned policy and institutional reforms over 
the  next  3  years.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  Uzbekistan  on  3-10  August  2007  and 
reached an understanding with relevant government agencies on the objective, scope, and 
implementation arrangements of the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Uzbekistan’s  geographic  location  in  the  heart  of  Central  Asia  allots  it  significant 
geopolitical importance and a critical role in regional and global integration. Also possessing 
great social and economic development potential, Uzbekistan has adopted a policy of gradual 
transition from a planned to a market economy. During the initial development stage after its 
independence, the country’s economic slump was less severe than those of other Central Asian 
countries,  and  recovery  to  its  pre-independence  level  was  faster.  This  phenomenon  was 
partially due to low industrialization, its cotton production, and self-sufficiency in energy.2 
 
3.  The  country’s  economy  has  demonstrated  3  consecutive  years  of  strong  growth, 
supported by accelerated exports, productivity gains in the agriculture sector, remittances from 
overseas workers, and favorable commodity prices. Due to the Government's conservative 
fiscal stance, the state budget marked a surplus in 2006. However, Uzbekistan’s economic 
growth has not reached its real potential, and its economy heavily relies on the few primary 
sectors. Furthermore, competition within the region and beyond has recently been intensified.  
 
4.  In August 2007, the Government approved the Welfare Improvement Strategy (WIS),3 a 
medium-term  development  strategy  for  2008–2010.  The  WIS’s  main  objectives  include  (i) 
securing highly sustainable economic growth complemented by increased employment and 
income generation capacity, (ii) creating favorable conditions by attracting private investment to 
sectors that impact growth and vulnerable populations, (iii) achieving comprehensive regional 
development within the country that corresponds to each region’s resources, (iv) increasing the 
quality of and access to basic social services and encouraging gender equality, (v) deepening 
structural  and  institutional  reforms  and  increasing  the  economy’s  competitiveness  through 
liberalization  and  development  of  the  financial  sector  and  the  strengthening  of  market 
institutions, and (vi) accelerating reforms in the public administration sector to boost efficiency of 
policy formulation and transmission mechanisms and to enhance public goods and service 
quality. 
 
5.  The WIS’s successful implementation requires continued government commitment to 
reforms.  There  is  also  a  need  to  develop  coherent  policies  and  strategies  that  can  be 
operationalized—and adjusted if necessary—to help achieve the WIS’s objectives.  
 
6.  The Government has initiated several important reforms aimed at strengthening the 
public finance sector and creating favorable conditions for private sector investment. Although 
these efforts have yielded positive results, more structural and institutional changes are needed

to sustain growth in sectors such as agriculture, international trade, and infrastructure. However, 
though some of these initiatives seem effective from each sector’s perspective, they do not 
correspond cohesively across sectors. There is no mechanism to identify and analyze linkages 
between different reform policies and their effects on the country’s overall development. In 
addition, no effective platform exists to facilitate discussion and the timely analysis of policy 
options among stakeholders or even decision-makers. Finally, even though Uzbekistan may 
possess adequate capacity to conduct analytical work for policy reforms, this capacity is not 
consolidated—it is scattered among various ministries, government-affiliated think tanks, and 
research institutions. These issues combined emphasize the need to develop mechanisms that 
can effectively use local capacity to help facilitate dialogue between experts and policy-makers. 
 
7.  This proposed TA aims to address these issues in the following sectoral and thematic 
areas identified by the Government and ADB in line with the country’s demand and capacity: (i) 
specialized economic zones; (ii) microfinance facility; (iii) macroeconomic policy and public 
finance reform; (iv) natural resources, e.g., agriculture extension, land use, and water; and (v) 
other issues relevant to ongoing reforms. Of these areas, the proposed TA will commence with 
policy analysis related to the specialized economic zone and impact on improved seed quality 
for sustainable agriculture. ADB will define other issues to be addressed with the implementing 
agencies (IAs) on a demand-driven basis. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be to enhance policy formulation capacity and to accelerate the 
reform process to a market-oriented economy. The outcomes of the TA will include developing 
mechanisms to facilitate analysis of various policy options, strengthening capacity for long-term 
strategic  thinking  for  sustainable  growth,  stimulating  policy  dialogue,  and  disseminating 
information to the public. The proposed TA will support high-level policy dialogue on reform 
agendas regarding economic, socioeconomic, natural resource, and institutional constraints 
based on sound policy analysis in priority areas. It will facilitate building multi-stakeholder 
partnerships through conducting these needed and timely analyses. Findings from the analyses 
will  be  disseminated  at  workshops,  seminars,  and  conferences  within  and  outside  of  the 
country.  
 
9.  Further, the proposed TA will enhance national capacity to conduct analyses and to 
implement reforms aided by (i) economic, social, and private sector updates, (ii) additional 
institutional  and  organizational  assessments,  and  (iii)  participatory  development  of  various 
policy agendas by  government  officials; researchers at  think tanks, research centers,  and 
universities; and participants from the private sector and civil society. Relevant reform issues 
will be identified in a highly participatory manner to ensure government ownership of outputs. 
Dissemination of findings and policy suggestions will also be emphasized. 
 
10.  The proposed TA is designed to produce four types of outputs:  
 
(i)  policy review and analysis in prioritized thematic areas that include identified 
reform agendas, outputs in publishable quality, and selected reform road maps 
and action plans if applicable; 
(ii)  platform  and  associated  networks  between  the  Government  and 
stakeholders, including development partners, for reforms in identified thematic

3
areas  through  focused  policy  discussions  in  meetings,  seminars,  and 
conferences, and invitation of international experts in open discussions;  
(iii)  policy retreats with the policy-makers in which stakeholders discuss policy 
reform issues based on findings from analyses; and 
(iv)  dissemination  of  information  and  provision  of  findings  from  analyses 
through  official  government  publications,  ADB  publication  series,  conference 
participation, and publication in peer-reviewed journals. 
 
11.  The proposed TA also will assist the Government in reform initiatives stipulated in the 
WIS. In order to ensure demand-driven processes and government ownership of the outputs, 
the TA’s design is flexible in providing timely responses to the Government’s requests. Its 
implementation scheme is also adaptable, so that the TA can immediately respond to emerging 
issues that the Government may encounter during its reform over the next 3 years. ADB will 
also engage local institutions so that the TA enhances local ownership of outputs. The TA will 
help contribute to knowledge accumulation on reform agendas and capacity building for local 
researchers and policy practitioners. It will also develop mechanisms to discuss reform issues 
cohesively and comprehensively, and its outputs will help to formulate a long-term strategy. 
During the TA’s implementation, its activities will be closely coordinated with the Central Asia 
Regional  Economic  Cooperation  Institute  (CAREC)  in  order  to  enhance  results  and  avoid 
duplication of work.  
 
12.  The proposed TA will also coordinate policy researchers in drawing on international best 
practices  and  experiences  from  relevant  transitional  economies.  It  will  commission  policy 
reviews  and  analyses  in  highly  relevant  reform  areas,  finance  policy  retreats,  convene  
in-country conferences with international experts, and support local researchers in presenting 
the results from policy reviews and analyses at international conferences and workshops. The 
TA  will  also  finance  policy  practitioners  to  participate  in  international  conferences  and 
workshops on policy analysis. It will create a government-oriented research network that draws 
on international economic reform best practices. The knowledge base for this network will be 
built during the TA’s implementation, and the TA will provide the repository of reform knowledge 
and expertise.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA seeks to (i) improve the analytical underpinning of sectoral policies, and (ii) 
assist in the development of a coherent, prioritized, and budgeted implementation strategy for 
the WIS. These actions include strengthening institutional arrangements for policy analysis 
coordination and implementation. The analytical framework will be guided by the WIS and 
ADB’s Country Strategy and Program for Uzbekistan.4 The TA will adopt a highly participatory 
approach that will include the facilitation of dialogue among policy-makers and stakeholders, 
including the Government, nongovernment organizations, civil society organizations, and private 
sector representatives. If any similar study was conducted in neighboring countries, associated 
researchers will be invited to present their findings. International and national consultants will be 
engaged  whenever  feasible  to  strengthen  domestic  policy  formulation  capacities,  national 
consultation workshops will review the TA’s findings, and the findings will be presented at local 
and international workshops and conferences.

14.  Policy  retreats  are  a  highlight  of  the  proposed  TA’s  outputs.  To  ensure  national 
leadership and ownership, the TA will convene demand-driven and outcome-oriented policy 
retreats for policy-makers based on results from the analyses. Policy retreats will also help 
identify key institutional reforms and capacity development priorities to enable effective and 
sustainable market reform. 
 
15.  Findings from the analyses and conclusions from policy retreats, if applicable, will be 
disseminated through all available channels, including but not limited to official publications, 
ADB publications, e-publications, and peer-reviewed journals. The proposed TA will finance 
stakeholders’  participation  in  international  conferences  to  reach  wider  audiences  and  the 
invitation of international researchers and policy practitioners to open discussions. Through 
dissemination of findings and continuing dialogue on reform issues, the TA will provide guidance 
to  the  Government  in  enhancing  implementation  of  its  reform  agenda  and  rebuilding 
partnerships with stakeholders, e.g., research institutions, private sector entities, civil society 
organizations, and development partners.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $950,000 equivalent, of which $800,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government has agreed to provide 
the balance of $150,000 equivalent in-kind, through counterpart staff, office space, furniture, 
administrative  support  services,  and  local  logistics.  The  details  of  the  cost  estimates  are  in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  Executing Agency. The Executing Agency (EA) is the United Information–Analytical 
Department on Economy and External Economic Relations, Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic 
of Uzbekistan. The EA will coordinate all TA activities, and ADB will monitor the progress of TA 
implementation.  
 
18.  Implementing Agencies. Each IA will be identified depending on the thematic issues 
and established at relevant ministries, think tanks, research centers, and universities. IAs will 
conduct  the  analyses  with  the  consultants  under  ADB  supervision.  If  applicable,  IAs  will 
organize expert technical workshops, policy retreats, policy reform seminars, and participatory 
stakeholder consultations. All documentary outputs of the TA will be under the joint ownership of 
the Government and ADB. 
 
19.  The EA, IAs, and ADB will be responsible for TA implementation. The TA task manager, 
an ADB staff member, will be responsible for coordinating with the EA and submitting the 
proposed schedule, detailed terms of reference, and budget for each thematic area. The EA will 
be responsible for managing the updates of TA implementation and the reform policy briefs.  
 
20.  Procurement. Any procurement under the TA will be conducted in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Procurement will be 
conducted by ADB, and all equipment will be turned over to the counterpart agencies upon 
completion of the TA. 
 
21.  Consulting Services. ADB will recruit international consultants and team leaders (14 
person-months) and national consultants (50 person-months), whose expertise fits the thematic 
areas identified by the EA. ADB will engage four international consultants and two national

5
consultants per international consultant. Facilitators (international, 1 person-month and national, 
5  person-months)  will  be  recruited  for  the  policy  retreats  and  various  conferences  and 
workshops. Russian and English language interpreters (national, 1 person-month), and Russian 
language translator (national, 1 person-month) will be recruited on an intermittent basis to guide 
report preparation, presentation, and dissemination of results to local stakeholders. Editors 
(international,  1  person-month,  and  national,  2  person-months)  will  be  recruited  on  an 
intermittent basis to finalize publication of TA findings for wide readership. ADB will engage the 
consultants on an individual basis in accordance with ADB's procedures for recruitment of 
individual consultants. Engaging individual consultants are more appropriate than firms because 
the assignments do not require a team of experts across different disciplines. Policy analysis for 
each  thematic  area  will  be  conducted  by  a  team  of  one  international  and  two  national 
consultants,  and  the  EA  as  well  as  ADB  will  supervise  TA  activities  throughout  TA 
implementation. The terms of reference are provided in Appendix 3. The TA is expected to be 
completed by the end of June 2010. 
 
22.  The  TA  consultants  will  organize  policy  retreats  and  national  and  international 
workshops and conferences, preparing detailed objectives, programs, and budgets for each 
event. Proposals for retreats, workshops, and conferences will be submitted to ADB at least 6 
weeks in advance for review and approval. Participants of retreats, workshops, and tours will be 
nominated by the EA at least 1 month before those events are scheduled to occur, and all 
nominations will be subject to ADB approval.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Policy and Institutional Reform Support, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Individual consultants for the technical assistance (TA) will be selected and engaged in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) procedures for recruitment of individual 
consultants.  The  TA  will  cover  (i)  drafting,  reviewing,  and  revising  papers  on  reform  in 
Uzbekistan and associated issues in Central Asia; (ii) conducting research and analyses, as 
well as writing reports, publications, and public presentations, on economic and private sector 
updates; and (iii) facilitating participatory dissemination of reform briefs by inviting international 
experts to Uzbekistan and organizing in-country policy retreats and workshops at international 
conferences. The consultants will also play key roles in researching networking activities and 
reviewing reform papers prepared under the TA to ensure that they incorporate international 
best practices to support sustainable growth and poverty reduction.  
 
2.  A mix of individual national and international consultants will draft policy briefs with the 
implementing agencies (IAs). The Executing Agency (EA), with support from ADB, will be 
responsible for managing the preparation of relevant policy reform reports, and facilitators will 
organize various workshops and policy retreats.  
 
A.  International Consultants (14 person-months, intermittent) 
 
1.  Macroeconomist (international, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  The macroeconomist will (i) have extensive experience working with governments and 
communities on economic issues; (ii) possess at least 5 years of experience providing economic 
policy  advice  to  governments;  and  (iii)  show  demonstrable  skills  in  macroeconomic  plan 
preparation and formulation. The consultant will hold at least a master’s degree in economics or 
a related field, and have excellent verbal and written communication skills. Research experience 
and publication in peer-reviewed journals will be assets.  
 
4.  The activities of this position include but are not limited to: 
 
(i)  supervising the work of the consulting team on macroeconomic issues; 
(ii)   preparing  sustainable  economic  policy  suggestions  in  line  with  the  Welfare 
Improvement Strategy (WIS) and the new long-term development strategy after 
WIS is completed, while also preparing target macroeconomic management and 
fiscal indicators that consider findings from other TA activities, other relevant 
reports, the Government, and other stakeholders; 
(iii)   recommending  future  activities  to  strengthen  sustainable  economic  policy 
formulation;  
(iv)   forecasting the long-run trend of price levels; 
(v)   simulating the results of and analyzing financial market conditions if liquidity 
constraints are relaxed; 
(vi)   preparing a medium-term fiscal management policy and budgetary framework; 
(vii)   organizing  in-country  workshops  for  experts  who  designed  the  medium-term 
macroeconomic development strategy for the post-WIS period;

(viii)   organizing  participation  and  presentations  at  international  conferences  and 
workshops  in  which  a  medium-term  development  strategy  or  medium-term 
budget framework is discussed; 
(ix)  organizing  a  workshop,  jointly  with  the  facilitator  and  other  consultants  if 
appropriate, with key stakeholders to discuss TA activities and draft outputs; and  
(x)  participating in workshops, and contributing as required to the TA’s inception, 
progress, and final reports. 
 
2.  Economist (international, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The  economist  will  (i)  have  extensive  experience  working  with  governments  and 
communities  on  economic  and  rural  development  issues;  (ii)  possess  at  least  5  years  of 
experience providing economic policy advice to governments; and (iii) show demonstrable skills 
in economic strategy and policy formulation. The consultant should hold at least a master’s 
degree in economics, agricultural economics, or a related field, and have excellent verbal and 
written communication skills. Work experience in Central Asia as well as research experience 
and publication in peer-reviewed journals are assets. 
 
6.  The activities of this position include but are not limited to: 
 
(i)  supervising the consultant team’s work on economic issues, including feasibility 
studies  on  specialized  economic  zones,  seed  market,  customs  unions,  and 
international trade, and analysis of development for light industry; 
(ii)   directing policy analyses with the IAs, leading to implement TA, and ensuring that 
international best practices are incorporated into the analyses; 
(iii)  preparing  a  rural  development  plan  to  identify  key  agriculture  and  rural 
development strategies and action plans; 
(iv)  advising the IAs on international best practices in similar networking activities, 
and incorporating them into the TA as appropriate; 
(v)  organizing  participation  and  presentations  at  international  conferences  and 
workshops  in  which  a  medium-term  development  strategy  or  medium-term 
budget framework is discussed; and 
(vi)  participating in workshops, and contributing as required to the TA’s inception, 
progress, and final reports. 
 
3.  Microfinance Specialist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The microfinance specialist will have a postgraduate degree in banking or finance and at 
least 10 years of experience in financial sector policy, institutional reforms, and reforming rural 
and microfinance systems at the policy and institutional levels. Experience in Central Asia or 
any former Soviet country is an asset. The consultant will also be well-versed in Uzbekistan’s 
microfinance policies, regulations, and institutional context.  
 
8.  The activities of this position include but are not limited to:

(i)  advising  government  officials,  as  well  as  private  sector  representatives  as 
requested, on policies supportive of microfinance best practices and how they 
may be incorporated into the Uzbekistan or Central Asian context; 
(ii)  reviewing decrees and orders related to microfinance and other legal documents, 
e.g., guidelines, regulations, and circulars, which are relevant for microfinance; 
(iii)  organizing  participation  and  presentations  at  international  conferences  and 
workshops in which microfinance legal and supervisory systems are discussed;  
(iv)  preparing a sector development framework that will incorporate, in the future, 
further development of microfinance; 
(v)  finalizing the review of the legal microfinance framework, and preparing policy 
suggestions; 
(vi)  organizing roundtable discussions on the TA’s findings with key stakeholders as 
needed; and 
(vii)  participating in workshops, and contributing as required to the inception, progress, 
and final reports. 
 
B.  National Consultants (50 person-months, intermittent) 
 
1.  Economists (national, 35 person-months, intermittent) 
 
9.  The national consultants for economic issues must have excellent communication skills 
and be able to liaise with all members of the Government, development partners, and civil 
society  to  ensure  the  smooth  planning,  delivery,  and  administration  of  the  TA.  These 
consultants will have at least 5 years of experience providing economic policy advice to the 
Government and civil society, and will hold tertiary degrees in related fields. They will also have 
working experience in, but not limited to, macroeconomics, public finance and treasury, financial 
markets, and the banking sector.  
 
10.  A local coordinator will liaise with the EA and other relevant government offices. The 
consultants will directly support the international macroeconomist and economists and other 
project members, the EA, the IAs, and ADB staff.  
 
2.  Agriculture and Rural Development Specialists (national, 15 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
11.  The  national  agriculture  and  rural  development  specialists  must  have  excellent 
communication skills and be able to liaise with all members of the Government, development 
partners, and civil society to ensure the smooth planning, delivery, and administration of the TA. 
These  consultants  should  have  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  economics,  agricultural 
economics, or other fields related to agriculture and rural development, and will hold tertiary 
degrees in related fields. 
 
C.  Facilitators, Editors, Translators, and Interpreters (international, 2 person-months, 
and national, 9 person-months, intermittent) 
 
12.  Facilitators will serve as focal points in organizing policy retreats and various workshops. 
Editors will coordinate with the IAs and consultants in formatting the policy briefs and analytical

1.  Facilitators  (international,  1  person-month  and  national,  5  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
13.  Facilitators will promote and manage institutional and policy development and be familiar 
with service delivery systems in Central Asia. These consultants will organize workshops, 
conferences, seminars, and other consultations, and will maintain clear communication with TA 
recipients.  
 
14.  The activities of these positions include but are not limited to: 
 
(i)  serving as the main organizers of the workshops, conferences, seminars, policy 
retreats,  and  other  consultations;  facilitating  the  invitation  to  and  travel  of 
participants  to  meeting  venues;  and  coordinating  and  ensuring  the  timely 
engagement of resource speakers; 
(ii)  liaising  with  concerned  offices,  partners,  institutions,  and  governments  in 
securing the appropriate decisions and actions to support the TA activities; and 
(iii)  organizing policy retreats, workshops, and conferences for senior management 
level staff of the Government to discuss policy suggestions. 
 
2.  Editors and Translators (international, 1 person-month, and national, 3 person-
months, intermittent) 
 
15.  Editors will be familiar with ADB’s style of writing, and editors and translators will be 
proficient in both English and Russian. Editors will work with relevant officials and staff at the EA, 
IAs, and ADB.  
 
16.  The activities of these positions include but are not limited to: 
 
(i)  revising and formatting analytical papers and other related documents prepared 
under the TA for ADB publication; and  
(ii)  coordinating with the IAs, ADB staff, consultants, and interpreters on reports to 
ensure accuracy of message and appropriateness of the language.  
 
3.  Interpreters (national, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
17.  Interpreters will work closely with facilitators at the workshops, conferences, seminars, 
policy retreats, and other consultations, and will interpret and translate Russian into English and 
vice versa.
